pros: Forward thinking management structure thruout
cons: Turnover is high and constant

pros: Highest minimum wage out of anywhere in the county ($16/hr as a starting wage is nothing to sneeze at). Good insurance.
cons: Everyone at this hospital hates each other. I don't think I've seen this much passive animosity at any job I've ever been at. If you're not a nurse, you're treated like you're on the bottom rung. Essential workers (i.e. custodians and point of care technicians) are treated like they aren't even human. A lot of this stems from the fact that everyone gets equal pay-- while this sounds great in theory, it doesn't mean that everyone thinks everyone else is on equal footing. It means that people who are "skilled" think they deserve better than those who do grunt work. This place is bleeding money to the point where they can't even afford overtime, and it's no wonder why; they must have to pay through the nose to settle constant patient rights lawsuits. While I can't go into it here because of HIPAA concerns, I have seen horrific things done to patients in this hospital, to the point where I'm wondering if I'm in 2023 or 1923. Diversity is non-existent; I literally have not seen a single non-white person working here. I would not recommend this business to any minorities, racial, sexual, gender-diverse, neuro-diverse, or otherwise. All of the higher-ups, and most of the staff, are VERY socially conservative.
